content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, liquid, plus 3 O 2, gas, react to produce 2 C O 2, gas, plus 3 H 2 O, gas; delta H naught of combustion, equals negative 1270 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1270</mn></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Ethanol, <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, will combust in air according to the equation above. A. Is <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> oxidized in the reaction, or is it reduced? Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, liquid, plus 3 O 2, gas, react to produce 2 C O 2, gas, plus 3 H 2 O, gas; delta H naught of combustion, equals negative 1270 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1270</mn></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Ethanol, <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, will combust in air according to the equation above. A. Is <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> oxidized in the reaction, or is it reduced? Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

B. When a sample of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> was combusted, the volume of <math alttext="C O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> produced was <math alttext="18.0 liters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when measured at <math alttext="21.7 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>21.7</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="1.03 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.03</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Determine the number of moles of <math alttext="C O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> that was produced.

C. Determine the volume of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, in <math alttext="milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, that was combusted to produce the volume of <math alttext="C O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> collected in part B. (The density of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.79 gram per milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.79</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.)
D. Determine the amount of heat, in <math alttext="kilojoules" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, that is released by the combustion reaction.

The combustion reaction occurred in a closed room containing <math alttext="5.56 times 10 to the fourth, grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.56</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of air originally at <math alttext="21.7 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>21.7</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume that all of the heat produced by the reaction was absorbed by the air <math alttext="specific heat equals 1.005 joules per gram per degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>(specific heat = 1.005 J/(g</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C))</mtext></mrow></math> in the room. E. Determine the final temperature of the air in the room after the combustion.

F. The boiling points of ethanol and dimethyl ether are provided in the following table. Identify the intermolecular force that is most responsible for the difference in boiling point. In terms of this force, explain why the boiling point of ethanol is higher than that of dimethyl ether. Compound Structural Formula Boiling Point <math alttext="in degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Ethanol <math alttext="78 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>78</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Dimethyl ether <math alttext="negative 24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

One method of producing ethanol is by the reaction of ethene and water, as represented below. <math alttext="C 2 H 4, gas, plus H 2 O, gas, is in equilibrium with C 2 H 5 O H, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo></mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="delta H naught equals, negative 45 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>45</mn></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext></mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> G. A chemist wants to run the reaction and maximize the amount of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, gas" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> produced. Identify two ways the chemist could change the reaction conditions (other than adding or removing any chemical species) to favor the formation of more product. Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
